answers.answer: Well, congratulations and my sympathy on your good and bad news.  At least you have some possibilities eliminated.  From our previous discussions, we're a little bit the same in the diabetic department.  It seems to me the way to not become one is to act like you are one.  But if you're just pretending to be diabetic, you don't have to take medicines for it!  Sort of a lose/win, I guess--lose the fun carbs and win the no-meds, I mean.Holly

question: First of all, thanks to Quix and Wonko on your help with my journaling.  I really appreciate your input.   I got the results from my GTT and bloodwork in the mail today.  Thanks to you all, I arranged that when I went for the tests!  The good news is, I am not diabetic, anemic, or deficient in B12.  I am however borderline type II Diabetes, which I already knew.  I guess it's time to work on that before I turn the corner.  The bad news is: I am not diabetic, anemic, or deficient in B12.  That means we still don't know what is causing my symptoms and it still could be MS.  Ohhh well, next Wednesday the EMG will tell more, I hope.  How tough is that test?  I am a bit scared about it.Bless you all,Mary Kay
title: Good news and bad news...
